NaOH Volume: 0cm³

0.00°C

working area

Experiment Procedure

1.

Using the dilute hydrochloric acid and the 50cm³ measuring cylinder, measure 30cm³ of dilute hydrochloric acid and pour into the polystyrene cup.

2.

Place the beaker inside the working area, and then stand the cup inside the beaker. This will make it more stable.

3.

Hold the thermometer in the acid for at least 1 second, to measure the temperature. Record it in the first blank column of the table.

4.

Put 5cm³ sodium hydroxide solution into the 10cm³ measuring cylinder and pour into the cup.

5.

Using the thermometer, measure the temperature of the solution in the cup. Once the reading has stopped changing, record this temperature into the next row in the table.

6.

Repeat steps 4 and 5 to add further 5cm³ amounts of sodium hydroxide to the cup. A total of 40cm³ needs to be added (the last few additions should produce a temperature fall instead of a rise).

7.

Repeat steps 1–6 and record the results in the second blank column of the table.

8.

Calculate the mean maximum temperature reached for each of the sodium hydroxide volumes. Record these means in the third blank column.

Help
